awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Toward a Scalable, Multi-Tenant, Edge-Cloud Infrastructure for Real-Time Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Applications are increasingly cloud-connected, and are dependent on fast service that is impossible if their requests must travel to a cloud data center. Edge-computing places a smaller amount of computation on the network very close to the applications themselves, providing fast servicing of requests.  This enables new application types such as virtual and augmented reality, which want to display information to users with imperceptible overheads.

Unfortunately, current cloud computing systems cannot support the density or diversity of applications found in edge-computing deployments. Each connected device -- be it a cell phone, a smart building sensor, or an autonomous vehicle -- may require different software to run in the edge cloud, and mobile users may constantly be arriving and departing. Since these software components cannot necessarily be trusted, resources must be carefully isolated to provide security and prevent interference. This research creates EdgeOS, which provides strong multi-tenant isolation while ensuring quick response times, and efficient use of computational resources.

EdgeOS introduces a number of system abstractions to enable multi-tenant edge-clouds: a new lightweight process abstraction that enables a very large number of clients to be served efficiently, and with isolation; controlled communication to ensure safe, efficient coordination; and system support for controlling the service time of various clients to ensure the timely processing of requests. These new operating system abstractions will help edge clouds realize their potential in offering low-latency services.

The EdgeOS research is paired with an educational initiative that will deepen the systems curriculum, engage undergraduate students in research, and involve a diverse body of students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background: This project has investigated if it is possible to provide a multi-tenant infrastructure for the network edge. This question is motivated by the massive impact that the cloud has had on computation. It enables companies to rent a compute infrastructure, instead of needing to buy it up-front. It powers many companies, and most startups.This project assesses the viability to taking this model to the network edge, and demonstrates that it is possible.

The network edge is a set of "micro-clouds" that are closer to the consumer requiring service. These are, for example, co-located with cell base-stations. The benefit of these systems is that they can interact with the client faster (with lower latency). It is particularly valuable for systems such as autonomous vehicles that can benefit from fast responses so that they can react nimbly. The challenge with these systems is that, unlike the cloud, they are relatively small, and limited in the number of computers devoted to each micro-cloud. The "for rent" model (otherwise known as multi-tenant) of computation is challenging when many tenants have to densely pack into a smaller set of resources.

Enabling an "edge for rent" execution model has a potentially large impact. Network infrastructure is expensive, and edge clouds are natually distributed (e.g. across mobile base-points), requiring many installations. Mobile carriers amortize the costs of their infrastructure with sharing arrangements (that use "network slicing"). The edge cloud requires client-specific computations, which are much more general and unpredictable compared to conventional network slicing. This complicates the sharing of the infrastructure, and security concerns redouble that complexity. The promise of the edge for rent is a new infrastructure that can accomodate delay-sensitive application-domains such as Augmented-Reality and Autonomous Vehicles.

EdgeOS: This project has created the EdgeOS system that manages the edge cloud systems. It has demonstrated the capability to do all of the following:

  1. Dense multi-tenancy: we create a new abstraction for computation that enables many different, potentially malicious, tenants (think: neighbors that insist on loud music) to safety share the same hardware.
  2. Efficient use of limited resources: the edge must process massive amounts of network data, thus the infrastructure is able to carry and transmit data efficiently from network, to tenant computations, and back to the network.
  3. Timely service: for the edge to be useful, it must be able to provide timely, fast replies to service requests, thus we enable explicitely controlling the latency (i.e. delay) of each request.

This combination of security (to handle multi-tenancy), density, efficiency, and controlled latency is unique to EdgeOS. It has created the abstractions, mechanisms, and policies that enable the vision of the edge for rent.

EdgeOS has been published in top scientific venues, received paper awards, and its research has resulted in the training of multiple PhD, Masters, and undergraduate students. This project has led to collaborations with Arm Research on latency-sensitive edge infrastructures, and with the Semiconductor Research Corporation on Augmented Reality and nanoprocess infrastructures.
